editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE EUNUCH. A TRAGEDY: As it hath been Acted with Great Applauſe.
LONDON, Printed by J. B. and are to be ſold by Randal Taylor near Stationers-Hall, 1687.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Dumaine and Lamot, like two Poor Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Dumaine.
sp.l: WE are not ſafe Lamot, this Bawdy Peace
Begets a War within me, our Swords worn
For Ornament not uſe, the Drum, and Trumpet
Sing Drunken Carrols, and the Cannon ſpeaks
Health, not Confuſion; Helmets turned to Cups;
Our bruiſed Arms adminiſter diſcourſe
For Tables, and for Tav • rns, where the Souldier
Oft finds a pity, not relief: Pl • tell thee
We are walking Images, the ſign of men,
And bear about us nothing but the form
Of man, that's manly.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Yes my Lamot, and • he ungratefull Time
As coldly doth reward ut, all our Actions,
Attempts of Valour look'd into with Eyes
Philmed with Contempt, when ye Gods, ye know,
It is our Gifts they ſee yet: Oh I am Mad!
The very Bread that lends them Life to ſcorn us,
Our Bloods have paid for, yet demand a bit,
Or ask of this Old-Sattin-Belly'd-Sir,
Or Madam-Toothleſs, with her Velvet Sconce,
And you ſhall hear their rotten Lungs pronounce
The Whip, and Whipſtock.

sp.speaker: Dum. Lamot,
sp.l: Thou know'ſt, I dare be Patient.
With what an equal Temper did I breath,
Under the Frozen Climate of the North,
Where in mine Arms, the Sheets of War, I Slept;
My Bed being feathered with the down of Heaven,
I have lain down a Man, and riſe a Snow-Ball;
Yet theſe have been my Paſtimes, which I have born
as willingly, as I receiv'd them Nobly.
The Queens black Envy which doth ſtill remain,
And peeps through every Limb ſhe bears about her,
Fated to ruine us, does not ſwell my Gall;
No, nor this willing Beggery I wear
To cloud me from her Malice; by the Gods,
This Baſtard-getting-Peace unſpirits me,
A greater corraſive to my Active Soul,
Then all paſt-ills whatever.

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: Cool your Rage,
And be as Wiſe as Valiant, this is not time
To vent your Paſſions like a Woman;
A Souldiers Tongue moves only in his Sword.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: You are an expert Tutor and I thank you;
Our Wrongs would add a Spirit to the Dead,
And make them fight our quarrels. Who comes here?
sp.stage: A Floriſh, Enter Landrey, 2 or 3 Lords, 2 or 3 Petitioners, who by his followers are ſlighted off; they as grived return back again, whilſt he paſſes on in State.
sp.l: The Minion to our Queen! Oh what a train
The Painted Peacock bears! Death! were I Jove
But only for this Gyant.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Theſe are the fruits of Peace, upſtarts, & ſlatteries;
Tell me Lamot, can this ſame Marchant-Man,
Think or Commit a Sin, tho' never ſo Horrid
But it is candid o're, and from his Vice,
Exceſſive praiſe, and plaudites ariſe.
Were I the King! but he is willfull Blind;
And by the Horns ſhe rocks him faſt aſleep,
Before the Wanton and hot-Blooded Queen
Should have the Licenſe, but to be ſuſpected
With ſuch a Knight of Gingerbred as this is,
A Guilded Fleſh-fly; I would lock Her up,
Yea chain the Evil Angel in a Box,
And Houſe her like a Silk-Worm.

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: Pardon Sir,
The good Old King's unable.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Worſe and Worſe,
And therefore muſt admit an upſtart-Page,
Now raiſed to Honour by his Lawleſs Luſt:
Mayor of the Palace, and the Duke of France;
The next ſtep is the Crown; Oh Peaſant State,
When Owls are aired in the Cedars top,
And Daws compare with Eagles.

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: Like to like.
What was our Fredegonde but Golſanda's Maid?
A Princeſs, (Oh my Soul!) ſo Heaven'd above her,
That Fredegonde appears a Hell of darkneſs;
Yet does our Childrick, our old doting King,
Set up a Diſhclout againſt a Diadem.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: 'Twere good the King would Execute them both.

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: Execute them! For his beſt Blood he dares not;
The no-Chaſt-Queen is great in Faction,
Followed and Sainted by the Multitude,
Whoſe judgments ſhe has linked unto her purſe,
And rather bought a Love then found it:
She has a working Spirit, an active Brain,
Apt to conceive, and wary in her wills;
Beſides, her Sons. (the Pillars of State)
Supports her like an Atlas, where the ſits;
And like the Heavens commands our faces beneath her.
She is the greater Light, the King a Star,
Which only glares but through her influence.

sp.speaker: Dum
sp.l: Heark the Thunder of the War; now! out of Tune,
This Peace corrupting all things makes them ſpeak.
What means this moſt Adulterate noiſe?

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: Receiv't.
This is a Night of Jubile, and the King
Solemnly Feaſts for his Wars happy ſucceſs:
Beſides his Sons and he are knit again;
We ſhall have Maſques and Revellings to Night.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Now the Great Gods confound this pick-thank noiſe;
The Drum and Trumpets are turn'd flatteries,
And Mars himſelf a Bawd to grace their Ryots.
sp.stage: Enter the Eunuch with two fair Suits, Hats, Feathers, Rapiers, and all things anſwerable, flings them a Letter, and to each a purſe of Gold; and after a little pauſe departs.
sp.l: What Viſion's this? 'Tis Gold both right & fair;
Sure I dream not.

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: I cannot tell, but he
That takes this from me ſhall full ſoon perceive
I do not ſleep nor ſlumber: 'Twas the Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: What Papers that?
If it be Chorus unto this dumb ſhew,
Read it Dumaine.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Daſterd Hand, why ſhak'ſt thou?
sp.stage: Takes up the Letter & ſeems to tremble.
sp.l: The Queen!

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: Blaſted Dumaine! Give me the Scrowl;
Were ſhe a Fury, nay the Queen of Hell,
Tho' every word did Thunder I would read it.

body.p:
As ye are Souldiers truly Valiant, we Honour ye; as poor, we pity ye, and have ſent ye that which will render ye as compleat Courtiers, as undaunted Souldiers: Damaine, Lamot, let is ſuffice we know ye, for our Eye is Every where, whilſt we remember your Works, we ſhall ſtudy to forget your Parents Injuries: Fear nothing, for your hitherto concealment
we will get your Pardons, and whilſt we breath, breath your kind Miſtriſs; if you dare truſt us, and build upon our Fortunes, appear at Court to Night ſo adorned as ſhall become your Honours and our Friends.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: How do you relliſh this? What now Lamot?

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: We'le take the Gracious proſſer of the Queen,
She's Princely vow'd our Friend; beſides what Ill
Can we expect from her, who might have ſent
Her Murdering Miniſter, and Slain us here
Had ſhe intended foul-play; ſhe is Noble.

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: When he fell, we were too young for Traytors,
Tho' not for Torments, had we been apprehended:
For in the high diſpleaſure of this Queen
All our Poſterity was doom'd: Some felt the Wheel,
Some Racked, ſome Hanged, others Impaled on ſtakes,
And had not we been then in Wittenburgh,
And paſt the fury of the Tyrants reach,
We'd added to the Number of the Dead.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: And think you ſtill we ſhall not?

sp.speaker: Lamot
sp.l: By my Life,
It's Murder to ſuſpect her, we'le to Court,
Our Lives are all that we can looſe, our fame
No Art can Murder, nor time raſe our name.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.p: What coference did they maintain with thee?

sp.speaker: Eunuch.
sp.l: None farther then the Language of their Eyes;
They look'd on me as if they meant me thanks,
Which their Amazement rob'd me of.

sp.speaker: Eunuch.
sp.l: No, deareſt Lady, they appeared to me
Like to the Silent Poſtures in the Arras,
Only the form of Men with ſtrange Faces.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Come take them then, they are our Enemies,
Whom I have Angled with that Golden Bait;
Their Parents waded in my Brothers Blood;
For which I'le be revenged of all their kin,
Did they increaſe as faſt as I could kill,
sp.stage: Draws the Curtain and ſhews a Picture.
sp.l: I'de ever Kill, that they may ſtill increaſe.
This Picture drawn by an Italian,
(Which ſtill I keep to whet my Anger on)
Does repreſent the Murther of my Brother,
For Raviſhing this Beauteous peice of Ill;
A Cruel and a Terrible Miſtake,
To Murther Clodymer, for Clotair's fact.
For which behold how Fredegond's revenged:
This old Dumaine and Father to this Maid,
With all his Kindred, Sociates, and Allyes
(Theſe brace of wicked ones, and this raviſht Whore,
The fair and fatal cauſe of theſe events
Only excepted) are here; here in this Picture.
Here's one bereft of Hands, and this of Tongue,
Finger thy Lute Maria, Sing out Iſabel,
Heark Heark, Caſtrat, the Muſick of the Spheres,
O raviſhing touch! Heark how the others voice
Ecchoes the Lute, Is't not a Divine ſoftneſs, Ha, ha, ha!
I do expect they now ſhould rail extremely;
I prethee Scould at me good Iſabel,
A little of the Woman; no! Maria,
Within the loathed Circle of mine Eyes
Anchor thy ſingers; Alas! thy Nails are pared;
Nor has poor Iſabel a Tongue to ſcould with:
Two hory Greybeards in this angle lyes,
Will find their way to Hell without their Eyes.
Villains that Kill'd my Brother, how does this relliſh thee,
To Execute Men in Pictures? Is't not rare?
Is't not a paſtime for the Gods to gaze on?

sp.speaker: Eunuch.
sp.l: Were but Crotilda here, and theſe two Youngſters,
It were a paſtime for the Gods to gaze on.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: We find the Eunuch fit for our Employments,
Therefore I will unclapſe my Soul to thee;
I've always found thee Truſty, and I Love thee.

sp.speaker: Eunuch.
sp.l: With thanks I ever muſt acknowledge it,
And lay my Life at my great Miſtreſs's feet
To ſpend it when ſhe pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: We need it not
As yet, Caſtrato, but we may hereafter.
See there's the Platform of great Childricks Death;
And they which muſt be thought his Murderers,
Our Enemies, and now new Courtiers;
Whom hitherto I have reſerv'd for Policy;
Firſt, that they take away the Guilt from us;
Next, being apprehended, ſtudied Deaths,
The Heads of all our Engineers ſhall' ſit
To invent unheard of Torments for the Slaves;
I long to ſee them here, here in this frame,
Greeting their Kindreds Bones.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Then I'le commend thee to my Elder Son,
Where thou ſhalt wind into his Secret Thoughts;
As for the Younger Boy let me alone;
And when we have them on the Hip, they ſhall
Follow their Father unto Hells black Hall.

sp.speaker: Eunuch.
sp.p: You are the Goddeſs of invention.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Will not this be Brave? Ha! how likeſt thou it!
Now by this Light I'me taken ſtrangely with thee;
Kiſs me, Kiſs me, cloſer Villain:
Fie! what a January Lip thou haſt,
A pair of Iſickles; ſure thou haſt bought
A pair of Eaſt Lips of the Chaſt Diana's;
Thy Blood's meer Snow broth: Kiſs me again.
Now ſee if you can find theſe Gallants forth,
And bring them to our preſence.
Oh Landrey!
Your Viſits have been freer, but I grow Old,
And you Command the Beauties of the time.

sp.speaker: Landrey.
sp.l: What means my Noble Miſtreſs? think you the Blood
Runs ſo degenerate within theſe Veins,
To ſtoop to an inferiouſ Embrace,
When I enjoy the beſt?

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: We are Betray'd.
I'le tell thee a good jeſt Landrey, wilt hear it?
This Morning dreſſing my Head, my Husband came,
And with his Switch, for he was then to Hunt,
A Gentle ſtroke he gave me on the back;
My fancy buſied then to make me fine,
Suppoſing it was you that ſported ſo;
Cry'd, my Landrey, in Story we ſtill find,
The beſt Knights ſtrike before, and not behind:
The King who always underſtood too faſt,
Quits ſuddenly my Chamber, what he intends
I cannot gueſs, unleſs it be our Deaths,
Which if he ſpeedily perform not, then
Know he ſhall never, for this Night concludes him;
My Sons I weigh not, thus, they have Rebell'd,
And taken Spirit of late to oppoſe my, will,
And contradict my Pleaſure in thy Love,
For which it is not ſafe that they ſhould Live;
The Kingdoms Heir ſhall be a Child of thine,
And Kings and Queens ſhall follow in thy Line.
Oh! are they come, they're welcome, take our word,
sp.stage: Enter Lam, & Dum. very brave, & the Eunuch.
sp.l: A Queens word, Fredegonde bids ye welcome

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Your Highneſs is as full of Grace as Mercy.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Riſe and follow us, we'le be your Guardian,
And Protectreſs.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Sheep for my Shambles, whom I have fatted up
Only for Slaughter; Things are on foot decreed,
Shall make ſome Smile to Night, and others Bloed.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Clovis at one Door, Aphelia and a Page with a Light at the Other.

sp.speaker: Clovis.
sp.l: My beſt Miſtreſs, what Angel brought you hither;
For I know my Lions attend your goodneſs?
Why weep you? Truſt me your Eyes ſeed pearl,
Bracelets for Gods to wear about their Arms.

sp.speaker: Aphelia.
sp.l: I am too fond, yet he Swears he Loves me,
I have believ'd him too, for I have found 〈…〉
A God-like Nature in him, and a Truth 〈…〉
Hitherto Conſtant. 〈…〉

sp.speaker: Aphelia.
sp.l: If this ſhould be diſſembled, not your Heart,
And having won my Souls affection,
Should on a Judgment more retired to State,
Fling off affection, and leave me in Love,
What Ill-bred-tales the World would make of me?

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: That Jelouſy I'le ſtrangle, take this Ring
As I that Diamond dazled by thine Eyes,
Whoſe Beauties Sickned' cauſe Eclips'd by thine
Be theſe the mutual Pledges of our Love,
Our Marriage before our Marriage,
And curſed be they that Seperate our Love,

Tho' France be one, or, what is greater,
〈◊〉 .
Are yor fears over now?

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.l: I dare no Ill,
And therefore doubt none.

div.stage: Enter King, Queen, Clotaire, Landrey, Dumaine, Lamot, Ladies and Attendance; with the Guard, and Eunuch.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Approach our Perſon nearer, for methinks
Y'ave honeſt faces, if your Hearts keep touch
To your outward Semblance, y'are a pair
Nothing but Death ſhall force from me.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Good, Good!
This Phyſick works.

sp.speaker: Queeen.
sp.l: I my Black Genius, ſuch a fatal Dram
I have adminiſter'd, will wing his Soul
With expedition to the other World:
His parts Eſſential, like a wearied Ghoſt
This Night forſakes his Inn, whence fled and gone,
Who knows where it ſhall lodge? Mark his looks,
See'ſt thou not Death thron'd in his hollow Eye?
Great Tyrant over Nature: See, obſerve.

sp.speaker: Eunuch.
sp.l: With looks inquiſitive I have beheld him,
But can perceive no alteration.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Thou art a Fool, and want'ſt the optique nerves
To pry into my Acts; where I lay trains
Death comes before the grief; The Sulpherous Match
Deſtroys the Powder with a motion ſlow
To what I work with: As Antumns aged Leaf,
In youth the prime and glory of the wood,
Not to be graſpt by hand, falls with a puff,
And what we could not touch but now, we tread on.
So Childricke.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh! Lend me thine Arm Dumaine,
sp.stage: Dum. and Lam. both buſy about the King.
sp.l: I know not what, but on the ſudden, ſomething—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How the Nat • -play and buz about the flame
That muſt Conſume them.

sp.speaker: Clotaire.
sp.l: What Star's Unſpher'd and walks upon the Earth,
Making our Night a Noon? methinks her ſight
Does Cute Blindneſs, and lends darkneſs Light.

sp.speaker: Eunuch.
sp.p: Huſh! We are obſerved, My Lord.

sp.speaker: Eunuch.
sp.l: Which, that French India,
Who Sweats under the Pride ſhe bears about her.
She with whom your Brother holds diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Moſt true, Nature has much befriended her;
Art ſure ſhe's Honeſt?

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.l: Snow's not purer Sir,
No Veſtal Virgin at the Altar hears
A Soul ſo incorrupt, ſo void of flame
That's looſly active.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Eunuch, be our ſelf;
Get but that Lady for me, thou conceiveſt—

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.l: She dotes upon you Brother, through his means
I'le think upon ſome Plot.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Deſer our paſtimes paſtimes till another Night,
I am not well at eaſe.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.l: Dumaine be wiſe, thy foot is in the Snare,
Fredegonde hunts, an when ſhe hunts, beware.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: No matter what, mind we his Majeſty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: There is an Aetna in me,
The Air I draw returns illuminate.
Phyloſophy, thy Element of fire's here.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Oh I Burn!
Fire, Veſuvius, Aetna, Veſuvius.—.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: His grace grows worſe and worſe, O my griev'd Heart!
Support him Gently Friends, Gently, Gently.

div.stage: Exit. Om. ma. Eu. and Aphelia.

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.l: I credit your report and will obey,
His mind is Honourable, like his Parentage,
His Single name has arm'd me, pray lead on.
sp.stage: A Screch within of all together Oh! Oh! Oh!

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.l: Heark Lady! There was a fearfull ſound,
I ſear the King's departed, let's withdraw.

div.head: SCENE IV.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.p: O diſmal, fatal Hour! Enter Clovis.

div.stage: Enter Queen, Dumaine, Landrey, Ladies, and the reſt of the Guard.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Stand off,
Preach Patience to the Sea, when the rude Wind
Swells her ambitious Billows above the Clouds;
And if thou Tutoreſt them to Peace and Silence,
I'le be as Calm as they.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: The Treaſon here,
And not the Traytor, quite confounds my Senſes,

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: Ignorance, dark as Hell; doubt ye the Traytors
I've brought a pair of Vipers to the Court,
Warm'd and reliev'd them with a ſting to Kill us,
Who could be author of this deed but they?
His new Boſom'd Friends have ſlain him.—

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Our Guard,
Lay Hands upon the Traytors.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: O Lamot!
We are betray'd, baſely beſet with Snares.
sp.stage: They fight back to back againſt the Gu. & ſeape.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Juſtice fight thou my cauſe with thine own Sword.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O Villains! would you let them ſcape? two Men
To paſs the ſtrength of our undaunted Guard;
This made my Soul, this grates my very Gall

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Make after them, and bring them back again;
Or by my Fathers Soul ye breath your laſt
Still art thou here Aphelia? Ha! I may
Uſe my Commanding Power now—Lead on;
Come Mother, Brother, Friends, pray let us go.
King ne're receiv'd a Crown ſo full of woe.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Old Briſſac and his Page, with a Taper.

sp.speaker: Briſſac.
sp.p: IS ſhe not come from Court yet?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.l: No my Lord.
I loſt her mid'ſt the amazed multitude;
Where doubtleſs frighted with the ſudden horror,
She has with other beauties of the Court
Retired her ſelf untill the Morning-Star.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: 'Tis very likely ſo! Yet do ye hear,
Call up your Fellows; I'le not to Bed to Night,
sp.stage: Exit Page, & Enter preſently with 2 Serving-men.
sp.l: My thoughts are full of Tempeſt, diſmal thinkings;
Where is my Son? Why went He not to Court?
Perhaps ſome Sacrilegious hands have ſeiz'd on her;
Courts are no Sanctuaries, ſhe's no Veſtal:
May be ſhe's ſafe, then why returns ſhe not?
Why ſends ſhe not glad Meſſengers of Health!
No! No! She's loſt, and I undone for ever!
Run to the Court, they move not, why ſo faſt?
Let me deliberate; that were to give
The Courtiers notice I have loſt my Daughter,
Whom they will then ſuſpect, and call her fame
Into an Ill conſtruction; No! no! no!
O my poor Daughter, my Aphelia!
sp.stage: Enter Charles Briſſac and Clovis Muffled in his Cloak.
sp.l: Oh Sir you'r welcome, where's your Siſter,
I muſt have her Sirrah and I will,
Where is ſhe, Charles, where is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Tut, Tut, Honour me no Honour,
Nor Father me no Father!
Where i • your Siſter, Sirrah?

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Within Sir, otherwiſe this Gentleman
Has loſt his Labour; he's come to Viſit her.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Hoyday, Hoyday, Hoyday! to Viſit her?
Plots, Plots, meer fetches; to Viſit her!
What at the dead of Night? when the whole World
Is Sunk in ſlumber, and our Luſty Youth,
As quiet as the Grave; to Viſit her!
O moſt ridiculous! to Viſit her!
Pray Gentleman conſider, does your Siſter keep
Times ſo Prepoſterous for Viſits in?
Makes ſhe a day of Night; or has ſhe been breed
As looſe as Lais, to love Night-Courtings?
Do not diſtract me thus, to Viſit her!

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Pray Sir collect your ſelf, this Gentleman
Even at that Horrid point where the King, fell—

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Why look you now, there is more Miſchief toward;
What a World is this?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Saw a Ring drop off my Siſters ſinger,
Which he had then deliver'd, but that fright
Which renders men forgetfull, made him ſo;
But knowing where ſhe lived, (ſo he proteſts)
He would not Sleep until it were delivered.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Pray let me ſee the Ring; Yes it was hers,
And ſhe would ſay, ſhe'd never part with it
But when ſhe meant to Wed, if you have Married her
Or have her promiſe rivited to yours,
Tell me but where ſhe is, I'le be content,
For I in loſing her, have loſt my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.p: O my Prophetique Soul, then 'tis no Idle fear.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.p: How! The Monſieur, what makes he here?

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: There's ſomething whiſpers me, go not to Bed,
Go not to Bed till thou haſt found her out:
Beeſt thou my Gonious, or what Powers elſe,
Suggeſting lawfull things I will obey thee.
Sleep ever-waking Envy and Miſtruſt,
Yet things that never knew what Slumber meant;
Ghoſts keep your Beds, ye Centinels of Night,
Goblins and Specters do not walk your round,
A general Lethargy Seize on this Hour,
Yet I alone the Watchman of this Night,
Will wake in ſpite of Fate. Argus thine Eyes
To find Aphelia and her Miſeries.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Pritty, in good ſadneſs, wond'rous pritty,
Is he in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Sure he diſſembles not.
I little dreamt when I did let him In,
What Perſon grac • d our Threſhold.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Ha Sirrah!
What a Girl's this to be out o'th' way?
He's in Love that's certain, Let me ſee.
When I was firſt a Lover as he is,
I'de juſt ſuch cold fegaries in my Brain,
Such Midnight madneſs. This puling Baggage
May loſe her ſelf for ever, and her Fortunes,
For this Hours abſence, go, be gone,
Follow his Royal Perſon, Comfort him,
Tell him my Daughter will again be found,
And ſo good Angels grant we meet with her.

div.stage: Exe. one at one door and the other at the other.

div.head: SCENE II.

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.l: Into what Laberinth do you lead me Sir?
What perplexed by-ways? I ſhould fear,
Had you not us'd his Name, which is to me
A Strengh 'gainſt Terror; and himſelf ſo good,
Occaſion cannot vary, nor the Night,
Youth nor his wild deſire; Otherwiſe
A Si •• nt Sorrow from mine Eyes would ſteal,
And tell ſ • d Stories for me.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: Do not fear,
You are too tender of your Honour, Lady,
Too full of agaiſh trembling; the Noble Prince
Is as December froſty in deſire,
Save what is Lawfull, he not owns that cheat,
Which were you Snow, would thew a tear from you.

sp.speaker: Eunu.
sp.l: I'le go call him,
In the mean time, pleaſe you to reſt your ſelf,
Here is a Little Book will bear you Company
sp.stage: Gives her a book, ſhe ſits down and reads.
sp.l: 'Till I return, which will be ſuddenly
Now Eunuch muſt the Artumie of Wit,
From the dull Mixture of theſe leaden Brains
Extract the Elixir of pure Villany.
Hither I'le ſend the King, not that I mean
To give him leave to cool his burning Luſt,
For Clovis ſhall prevent him in the Fact;
And thus I ſhall Endear my ſelf to both:
Clovis Enrag'd perhaps will kill the King,
Or by the King will periſh; if both fall,
Or either, both ways makes for me.
The Queen as rootedly does hate her Sons,
As I her Ladiſhip; to ſee this fray
She muſt be brought by me. It ſhall be ſo;
Her breath will ſtir in them confuſed Storms,
In midſt of whoſe wild rage, the Court will ſeem
A G • lgoth • e of Miſchief; for her ſake
I'le ſay I ſet on foot this hopefull brawl,
Whilſt ſhe will Hug, and Kiſs me for the ſame:
Thus on all ſides, the Eunuch will play foul,
And as his face is black, he'l have his Soul.

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.l: Poor raviſh'd Philomel, thy lot was ill
To meet that Violence in a Brother,
Which I in a Stranger doubt: Yet methinks
I am too Confident, for I feel my heart
Burthen'd with ſomething ominous; theſe men,
Are things of Subtle Nature, and their Oaths
Unconſtant as themſelves—Let me proceed.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Methinks I ſtand like Tarquin in that Night
When he defiled the Chaſtity of Rome,
Doubtfull of what to do, and like a Thief
I take each noiſe for an Officer.
Tho' I do know it is a deed of Death,
Condemned for Torments in the other World,
Such tempting ſweetneſs dwells on every Limb,
That I muſt venture my Eſſential parts
For the fruition of a moments Luſt:
Oh Pleaſure dearly bought.

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.l: Clovis may prove unkind, alack why not?
He's but a man. Say he ſhould offer foul,
The Evil Counſel of a Secret Place,
and Night his Friend, may out-tempt his will:
I dare not ſtand the Hazzard, Guide me Light
To ſome Untrodden Place, where poor I may,
Wear out the Night with ſighs till it be day.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: I muſt be bold and reſolute; Sweet Maid,
Fair, Virtuous Damſel, Hail.

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.l: What man art thou,
That doſt thy Countenance bury in thy Cloak,
And hideſt they face from Darkneſs and the Night?
If thine intents deſerve a Muſler too,
And that thy thoughts dare non allow themſelves.
Withdraw, and Act them not, what art thou? ſpeak,
And wherefore cam'ſt thou hither?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Wouldſt thou know?
I came to find one Beautiful as thou,
And am a man willing to pleaſe a Woman.
Nay, nay, you muſt not leave mo thus.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: No, muſt not, 'tis I that ſpeaks it Lady.

sp.speaker: Cloth.
sp.l: But I muſt you, yes and the right way too,
Which is th' acquaintance ſureſt.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Nay, nay, nay, none of your Prick-Songs Lady,
If you riſe a Note, or beat the Air with Clamour,
You ſee your Death.

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.l: What Violence is this?
Why do you threaten War, fright my ſoft peace
With moſt ungentle Steel, what have I done
Dangerous, or am like to do? why do you wrack me thus?
Mine Arms are Guilty of no crime, do not torment 'em,
My Hands and they have joyn'd in Prayer together
For mankind that is Holy; if in that Act
They have not Pray'd for you, mend and be good,
The fault is none of theirs.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: You gueſs my Mind
What Earthquake ſhakes you thu?
Come do not ſeem more Holy then you are,
I know your Heart.

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.l: Let your Dagger too, Noble Sir ſtrike home,
And Sacrifice Soul to Chaſtity,
As white and ſpotleſs as her Innocence

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: This is not the way.— Know you me Beauty?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: The ſame, Riſe up and put off ſear.

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.l: I dare not ſear, it's Treaſon to ſuſpect
My King can think an Ill, worſe to Act it:
I know you'r God like good, and have but try'd
How far weak Woman durſt be Virtuous

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Pritty Simplicity, thou art deceived:
Thy Wit as well as Beauty wounds me, and thy To •••
In pleading for thee, pleads againſt thy ſelf:
It is thy Virtue moves me, and thy Good,
Tempts me to Acts of Evil: wert thou bad,
Or looſe in thy deſires, I cou'd ſtand
And only Gaze, not Surfet on thy Beauty;
But as thou art, let me not ſee thy face,
I'me deſperate grown in Ill, and muſt enjoy
thee, or not thee thy Life.

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.l: I offer it.
You are my King and may Command my Life,
My will to Sin you cannot, you may force
Unſancted deeds upon me, Spot my fame,
And make my Body ſuffer, not my mind.
When you have done this irreligious deed,
What Trophy, or what Triumph will it bring,
More then a living Scorn upon your Name?
Do not believe this deed can lye conceal'd,
For Kings appear when they are Thron'd in Sin,
Like to prodigious Creatures in the Air,
At which all Tongues are mute, all Eyes do ſtare.
Is't not a Single Ill which you commit:
What in the Subject is a pe • ty fault
Monſters your Actions, and's a ſoul offence:
You give your Subjects Licenſe to offend
When you do teach them how.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Good, Ill apply'd:
I will endure no longer, come along,
Or by the curious Spinſtry of thy Head,
Which Nature's cunning'ſt ſinger twiſted out,
I'le drag thee to my Coach: Tempt not my fury.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Can I endure this; O my Salt Blood
Leap from my Boſom, up into the Air.
Unhand me Charles, and render me my ſelf,
Leſt I forget my ſelf on thee.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Great Prince,
Remember 'tis your Brother and the King.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Oh that I could forget it, and ſhake off
Duty at once, and Conſanguinity,
That like a Whirlwind I might ruſh upon him,
And bear him to Deſtruction—Monſter of men,
Thou King of Darkneſs, down unto thy Hell,
I have a Spell will lay thee, Honeſty,
And this abuſed Goodneſs: Is't not enough
That thou haſt wronged Crotilda, raviſht a Maid
A Virgin of that Purity of Life,
Might Saint Her here on Earth; but wilt thou add
Unto thy Firſt a Second Violence?
The Gods muſt not forgive!

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: I deſpiſe thee;
If thou wouldſt gain our Love, be a Brother,
And aid me in my longings.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Be a man;
And ſhake a Nature off, that needs muſt damn thee:
O ſet a Period to Sins Progreſs here,
Proceed not in theſe Courſes, leſt you grow
As Great in Sin as Scepter.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Traytor, Boy!
Thy fate moves in thoſe words.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Is't even ſo;
Then Guard thy ſelf our King, for I am quick
As Lightning, or the thought that Executes.

sp.speaker: Char.
sp.l: Hold hold, my Lord, forbear; Call in more aid,
Ring out the Alarum-Bell, Call up the Court,
Beſtir thee Eunuch, whilſt interpoſe
My Body to the fury of the Storm.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What means this ſudden out-cry? Oh my Sons!
Hold, Hold! Part them good Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Mother you are a trouble, ſtand from mine Arm,
Let me cut off Rebellion in the Spring,
Leſt it beget a harveſt that will prove
Fruitfull in Treaſon, Brav'd by a Subjects hand.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Though Nature by Precedency of Birth,
Made thee his King, it therefore follows not
His Murtherer; wherein is our Clo ••• r •
Greater then Clovis? Know, the ſelf-ſame Blood
That Spirits thee, makes him as Valiant,
The difference lies in Anno Domini.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I grant thou art his Elder; by which Law
Thou art born his Subject, not his Equal, Clovis;
For Clotaire is thy King, and Subjects hands,
Without the deep and dangerous Trayto •• Name,
May not advance againſt their Sovereign, Head.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Neither ſhall his without correction:
Upon him Slaves.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Hold, I Command ye hold.
O Clotaire, thou art of a Valiant Soul,
And wilt thou baſely thus beſet thy Brother?
Fear Argues ſpirits moſt degenerate,
And that thou ſeareſt th'advantage argues i •
Oh ſet not on thy Slaves; if he muſt dye,
Let thy hand Sacrifice, not Butcher him.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: That Argument Sounds harſh; ſhall Clotaire, fear?

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.p: Exquiſite Philter, Poyſon to the height.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.p: Sacrifice me, it is not in his Power.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: We hope ſo Clovis; yet thy Brother King,
Is as an Earthly-God, his Will, his Law,
His Power uncircumſcrib'd, unlimited,
For Kings have will as uncontroul'd as fate,
And Majeſty can look a Subject dead.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.p: How look me Dead? I do not fear his frown • .

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I Grant thee as great a Baſaliske as he;
As he is meetly man: but as thy King,
Divinity does prop him; he ſtands ſure
That builds on that Foundation: Yet I know
Thy Sword's as Sharp as his, and where it lights
Imprints as much of fate, thine Arm as ſtrong,
Thy Spirit as daring, and thy will as prompt
To any Action that may right a man.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: He is your Darling, you do well to praiſe him;
When I have ſlain him, Write his Epitaph.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: My Epitaph, this Pen of Steel ſhall firſt,
Write on thy Heart, thine end.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: It Operates.
The Venom'd Potion of a Womans Tongue
Is more ſublim'd then Mercury.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Our Guard
That let's a Traytor pull me by the heard:

stage.hi: They fall upon him with th • r Halberts and he's Slain.

sp.l: Cut him to peices Raſcalls.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O my Son!
Villain, thy Hands have made theſe holes, for which
The winged Vengeance of a Mothers Curſe
Subtler in Operation then Lightning,
Strike thro' thy Body every Limb a Death.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: How cunningly ſhe ſpits her Poyſon forth,
I know her Soul is Light, ſhe's glad he's Dead,
And joys in the opportunity to Curſe the killer;
For which ſhe gains the name of Pious Mother:
Here's pritty Woman Villain, diſſimulation.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: If they have ſlain him, wherefore do I Live?
O my ſwoln'n Heart.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Bear hence theſe Corps, withall
Remove that Syren from our wandring Eyes,
sp.stage: Landrey and 2 or 3 Lords more ſeem to Sollicite for Aph.
sp.l: And Cage her in a Dungeon, hence begone,
Bear her to Priſon, reaſon not the Cauſe
A Kings Prerogative's above his Laws.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: Be mercifull, and lead to Death, away;
Since he is gone, it is to Dye, to ſtay.

div.stage:
Exeunt Omnes, manen •
Queen, Landrey, Eun.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Now we begin to ſlouriſh, this black Night
Is only lighted by our ſtars, that ſmile
Upon theſe actions, and rejoyce to ſee
Thee our ſole Favouſite ſo near a Crown:
But tell me Landrey, how did I play the Mother?
Did not I preſent a Niobe, in paſſion,
Did'ſt thou not fear an Inundation.
A deluge of Salt Rhume?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: You had no coſtive Eye, that I dare ſay,
For certainly you wept.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Yes; as a good Actor in a Play would do,
Whoſe fancy works as if he waking dreamt
So ſtrongly on the object that it Copes with,
Shaping realities from Mockeries;
And ſo the Queen did weep: By this good Light
I think I could become the Stage as well
As any ſhe that ſells her Breath in publick.
Come ſhall we Act Landrey?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Act great Lady;
What Play ſhall we Enact?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Dull Landrey,
Nothing that's new, Old Plays you know are beſt:
Eunuch is our Bed ready.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Come then my Joy to Bed, where we will ſport,
And laugh at Death, which Triumphs in the Court.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Go ſleep your laſt; I'le ſtraight unto the King,
And he ſhall take them in the very Act;
And then to Cover my Diſcovery
I'le ſet on fire the Queens Bed-Chamber,
That ſo I may diſturb them more ſecure,
And yet the Plot not mine: I'le tell the King
Unleſs he preſent Help, his Mother burns.
About is then, this is a happy Night;
The more it works their Woe, more's my delight

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.l: LOok how it flames! I fear ſome Treachery;
Beat at her Chamber-door, cry it aloud,
And let your Voice be Thunder to this Lightning.
Cry Fire, Fire, Fire! The Court is all a Hot-houſe.
Fire, Fire, Fire!

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Great Queen, Royal Mother, open your door,
Leſt you do ſleep for ever, Mother awake.
The God of ſleep lies heavy on her Eyes.
Force open the door, Fire, Fire, Fire!

sp.speaker: Eun.
sp.l: It's fortified 'gainſt ſtrength, you muſt call lowder.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Mother, Queen, Mother, awake, awake!
Your ſleep was never liker death then now:
Lady, Great Princes, Fire, Fire, Fire!

div.stage: Enter Queen above in Night attire and Landrey.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What Sawcy Groom
Beats our offenceleſs doors thus daringly,
He'd better rous'd a ſleeping Lioneſs,
Then thus to have broke our ſlumbers.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Look,
The Fire will give you Light, 'tis I your Son;
Ely from that Chamber, elſe you are but dead,
Your Court is all a bonefire.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Let it burn.
I've loſt my Credit everlaſtingly,
I will not move a-foot.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: You muſt be forced then.

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.l: Where are your wits now in neceſſity,
We ſhall be taken, and you ſham'd for ever;
Bethink, Bethink your self.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I have't, it ſhall be ſo; there put on that,
Appearing in his Brothers Warlike Shape.
Thou wilt amaze, and ſo paſs by him ſafely.
Do not appear to me, I did not wound thee;
Seek out the Beds of thoſe that caus'd thy death,
And howl to them thy pittfull Complaint.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Whom do you hold diſcourſe with, with the Air?
Bethink your ſelf, this is not time to dally.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh, my Son, ſuch horrid apparitions, full of dread have I beheld, have quite unwitted me:
Your Brothers Ghoſt, fearfully terrible,

Has thr •••
• his diſmal night appear'd to me:
His Wou ••• did bleed, juſt as our Clotaire caus'd them,
To thoſe 〈◊〉 points, and calls Aphelia
To bear 〈◊〉 companyi' th'other World,

Or elſe 〈◊〉
• ightly haunt us in our ſleeps;
Thrice d •• be •• y Revenge, and with that word
Sprang 〈◊〉 the roof, which now ſtands bare to Heaven,
Where 〈◊〉 did rain down fire which here we ſee.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Oh fear it not my Son.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: What art thou that uſurp'ſt this dead of night
In me • tal like the ai • ? Why art thou ſent
To caſt a horror on me? If thy Soul
Walks unrevenged, and the grim Ferry-man
Deny thy paſſage, we'le perform thy rights;
Oh do not wound me with ſuch piteous ſigns
Leſt I diſſolve to air, and like thy ſelf
Aſtright fool-Mortals: If thou deſireſt
Aphelia's death, t'appeaſe thy troubled Soul,
Make ſome conſenting ſign and ſo depart,
Thy ſight afflicts my Soul.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Oh I am full of faintings, nothing but Aphelia?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: She muſt dye, you ſee it's requiſite.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Would he had askt my life firſt.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Why ſhould you be ſo fond upon a Woman,

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Woman's the leaſt part in her, ſhe's all goddeſs.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: 'Twas your offer;
Remember there's no jeſting with the gods.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: What might this mean? ha? where are my brains?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: I had forgot my ſelf, your pardon Mother:
Bear her from me this Jewel, I eſteem
Equal with life, it was my Brothers Picture;
And with it, this, that ſhe prepare to dye
Tell her, and if you can be moved to ſorrow
Expreſs it in your tears, it is not I
Pronounce this fatal Sentence 'gainſt her life,
But the hid will, and Providence of Heaven;
Againſt the which to be offended, were
As impious as not obey. Caſtrato ſtay,

stage.hi: Exeunt • nines manet Eunuch who profers to go out.

sp.l: And with thy COuncel cure thy dying Prince,
Thou art my boſome, Eunuch, and to thee
I dare unclaſp my Soul: What's to be done,
This is a damned Spirit I have ſeen
And comes to work my Ruine.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: My Brothers Spirit in Arms, here it came forth,
Here, from my Mothers Chamber as I knockt.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Was it in Armour ſaid you? what in Armour?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Yes in the Armour he was us'd to wear
When we have run at Tilt, 'till our cleft Spears
Have with their ſplinters ſcar'd the Element.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: That Armour as I well remember, I did leave
In the Queens Bed-Chamber, as yeſterday
After the Triumphs and the Turnements,
Having unbrac't the Prince: 'tis even ſo.
Why this is a ridiculous Paſſion.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: My ſtate requires thy tears, and not thy mirth.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: The Devil came from your Mothers Chamber Sir,
She has a Circle which can raiſe a Spirit,
A Mars in Armour too; ſhe is a Venus,
And through your Licenſe Landrey is no Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: What killing ſenſe thou utterſt,
There's ſomething in it I would underſtand
And yet I dare not. Landrey! how know'ſt thou this?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Since I have gone ſo far I'le tell you.
I look'd in at the Key-hole, and I ſaw
Him in your Mothers Arms, as ſportingly
As e're I ſaw your Father.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Thou haſt ſhot Poyſon thro' me:
Falſe with Landrey her ſometime-Page!

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: It's not impoſſible,
My Mother always had a ſcanted fame,
His thoughts to have been mine: I am diſtracted.
Was he the fearful Viſion that I ſaw?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: But wherefore would they have Aphelia dye?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: There lies the Myſtery,
They fear you will accept her as your Queen,
And fruſtrate their intents, who but expect
Your hop'd for death, that they might ſo become
(What now you'd croſs) Lawfully Man and Wife
And Govern in your Seak.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: This carries ſhew of truth, or is't a lye
Well ſhaddow'd by a Slave? I cannot tell;
My Mother certainly is not ſo bad,
It is a ſin to think it: Hence, avoid my ſight,
Thou ſower of debate, thy Seeds are ſtrow'd
On ſteril ground, and therefore ill beſtow'd.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Is't even ſo? work and about my brain
I'me loſt for ever if not cloſe again.

sp.speaker: Lanoue.
sp.l: Are all your Troops well furniſh'd gainſt reſiſtance?
Are your men bold and daring? reſolute
To run your hazzard? indifferent rich, not poor
That only fight for Bread? ſuch oft betrary
The ſinews of a well-knit Plot for gain,
When theſe as well fight to deſend as win.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Noble Lanoue;
Mine know, nor fear, nor death; Souls of that fire
They'l catch the Bullet flying, ſcale a Wall
Battled with Enemy, ſtand Breaches, laugh
The Thunder of the Canon, call it Muſick
Fitter a Ladies Chamber then the Field;
When o're their heads the Element is ſcaled,
Darken'd with Darts, they'l ſight under the ſhade,
And ask no other roof to hide their heads in;
They fear not Jove, and had the Gyants been
But half ſo ſpirited they had dethron'd him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: They're Soldiers fit to ſack a Kingdom then,
And ſhare the ſpoils between them.

sp.speaker: Bur.
sp.p: Were it come to that ſport once—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Burbone it muſt, or ſome of us muſt fall.

sp.speaker: Mart.
sp.p: Believe it not, for it is full of hazzard.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.p: So is the general enterprize in hand.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Give us a reaſon why you would invade
The Pallace firſt, and we are ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: Now you ſpeak like your ſelf:
Then underſtand, Lamot lives ſtill at Court
Diſguis'd like a poor Chyrurgeon,
To whom the Prince being delievered
to be Embalm'd and Bowel'd, finding life
Yet in his Corps, which may he's very Skillfull;
Has balſom'd all his wounds and cur'd him.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: And what of this? This makes againſt us quite.

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: I did but even now receive this letter,
Which conſtancy affirms it from himſelf.
He ſays it is not known in Court, the Prince to live
For divers reaſons beſt known to themſelves,
And herein doth require of ſecreſy;
Therefore dear friend divulge it not.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: He ſays the Princes ſuppoſed funeral
This day is ſolemnized with greateſt pomp,
And that Aphelia dyes a ſacrifice,
That hour he is buried, on his Herſe:
What if we made attempt to ſave the Virgin?

sp.speaker: Dum.
sp.l: That muſt not be, better ſhe fall alone
Then all of us together; and now beſt Friends,
Let's behave us bravely; it's no baſe act
We undertake, but our whole Countries freedom
From ſlavery and bondage, Men of worth ſtand bare
To Pages, and gilt butterflies, beſides the Queen
Will grave us all, rather then want ſport
In ſpilling Humane bloud; come let's withdraw,
And lay the Platform of this mighty work:
My Soul ſits ſmiling in me I Divine,
Though now it lowre we ſhall ſee Sun will ſhine.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Clovis, and Lamot diſguis'd like a Chyrurgeon. Recorders.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Strephon, for ſo thou nam'ſt thy ſelf, thou'ſt made
Thy Prince thy Subject, by this timely cure,
This is the hour I muſt be buried living,
And with me the Fair Aphelia, Strephon
Is it ſo?

sp.speaker: Lamot.
sp.l: Nay this the very Minute,
Hark, I hear them coming—

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Lend me thy Cloak
Here we'le obſerve the Mourners.

div.stage: Recorders. Enter King, Fredegond, and attendance, and Eunuch at one door in Mourning as after the C • p • of Clovis; at the other Aphelia led by two boys, a Headſman before as to Sacrifice, all in White, the Herſe is ſet down between both the Companies, Aphelia we pin • at one End, and the King at the other, who after a little pauſe speaks as followeth; after theſe Old Briſſac weeping.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Thou Royal load of Honour, burthen of grace,
Fitting an Atlas Shoulder, which he groans
More then the Spheres and Sweats thy weight not theirs;
Let me bedew thy Herſe with pious tears,
(Balm to thy wounds) repenting ones;
Behold this ſpotleſs ſacrifice, a virgin,
As pure in thought as veſture, an oblation
To ranſom Jove and Heaven had they been taken,
And ſo we yeild her up.

sp.speaker: Briſ.
sp.l: Oh my good Lord,
This is conſpiracy 'gainſt an old mans life,
Have you no other way to murther me
But to begin with Her? Why muſt ſhe dye?
Becauſe ſhe's fair? or that—

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.stage: the King takes the Sword from the Headſman.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Contain your ſelf
You may prevent the danger when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Behold the Conqueſt of thine eyes Aphelia,
France at thy foot, tread on his Royalty,
Or if thy Nature knows not to forgive;
sp.stage: the King kneels and lays the Sword at Aphelia's feet.
sp.l: Which to believe were impious, take this Sword
Send me a willing, willing ſacrifice,
T'appeaſe the troubled ſpirit of this love.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: O Eunuch that ſhe'd take him at his word.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: I find 〈◊〉 ſpeaking pitty in thine eyes,
Which thence will drop upon thy gentle tongue
And cry, In peace long live my Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Aphe.
sp.p: Long live Clotaire, long live my Sovereign.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: The Motions of the Spheres move in that tongue:
Turn all your Sables into ſutes of Joy,
Your dirges into ſprightfull wedding airs:
Why looks our Court ſo ſad, is this a time
To anchor your aſpects unto the earth?
By my bleſt ſelf he's a traytor to the height
That does not ſtreight Salute her as his Queen.
sp.stage: they ſting off their Mourning Cloaks.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Long live Aphelia, Queen of France, and us.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Do you hear this? what are you Planet-ſtruck? Glovis, Prince, Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Now, now, prevent them yet, are you a ſtone?
Have you a working Pulſe? O Statue-Prince
Thou art undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Where am I?
Awake! for ever rather let me ſleep:
Is this a Funeral? oh that I were a Herſe,
And not the mock of what is Pageanted.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Amazement quite confounds us, Clovis alive!

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Oh that in nature I could find an art
Could teach me to forget, I ever lov'd
This, her great maſter-piece. Oh well-built frame
why do'ſt thou harbour ſuch unhallow'd gheſts
To houſe within thy boſom, Perjury?
If that our Vows are regiſtred in heaven
Why are they broke on earth? Aphelia
This was a haſty match, the ſubtle air
Has not yet cool'd the breath, with which thou ſwor'ſt
Thy ſelf into my ſoul; and on thy cheeks
The print and path-way of thoſe tears remain
That woo'd me to believe ſo: Fly me not,
I am no Spirit, touch my active pulſe
And thou ſhalt find it make ſuch harmony
As youth and health enjoy.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Is there a god left ſo propitious
To rid me of theſe fears? ſtill lot her ſleep;
For if ſhe wake (O King) ſhe will appear
Too Monſtrous a ſpecter for frail Eyes
To ſee, and keep her Senſes.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Nothing ſo happy, Strephon, I would I were.
In times Swift-progreſs, I deſpair the hour
That brings ſuch comfort with it; I ſhould then
Forget that ever ſhe was pleaſing to me,
I ſhould no more remember ſhe would ſit
And ſing mo into Dreams of Paradice,
Never more hang about her Ivory Neck
Believing ſuch a one Diana was;
Never more doat ſhe breaths Arabia,
Or Kiſs her Corral Lip into a paleneſs.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Clovis what's paſt we are content to think
It was ſpoken by our Brother, and not our Subject,

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: I had forgot my ſelf; yet well remember
Yon Gorgon has Transform'd me into Stone,
And ſince that time my Language has been harſh,
My words too heavy for my tongue, too earthly;
I was not horn ſo; Truſt me Aphelia
Before I was poſſeſt with theſe black thoughts
I could ſit by thy ſide, and reſt my head
Upon the riſing pillows of thy Breaſt
Whoſe natural ſweetneſs would invite mine eyes
To ſink in pleaſing ſlumbers, wake and kiſs
The Roſe-bods that afforded me ſuch bliſs.
But thou art now a General Diſeaſe
That cateſt into my Marrow, turn'ſt my blood
And makeſt my Veins run Poyſon, that each ſenſe
Groans at the alteration. Am I the Monſieur?
Does Clovis talk his ſorrows and not Act?
Oh man be womanized; wert thou not mine
How comes it thou art his?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: You have done ill,
And muſt be taught ſo; you Capitulate
Not with your equal, Clovis ſhe's thy Queen.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Upon my Knees I do acknowledge her,
Queen of my thoughts, and my affections,
O pardon me if my ill tutored tongue
Has forfeited my Head; if not, behold
Before the Sacred Altar of your Feet
I lie a willing Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: Ariſe:
There he • a depth in face, which earthly eyes
May faintly look into but cannot f • thoſe
T •••• had'ſt my Vow 'till death to 〈◊〉 thy Wiſe,
You 〈…〉

A •••
〈…〉 beſtowed.
A long-farewell to Love; thus I do break
Your Pledge of broken faith. And with this Kiſs,
The laſt that ever Clovis muſt print there
Un-kiſs that Kiſs which ſeal'd it on thy Lips:
Ye Powers ye are unjuſt, for her wild breath
(That has the Sacred tye of Contract broken)
Is ſtill the ſame Arabia that it was.
Nay I have done; beware of Jelouſy;
I would not have you nouriſh jelous thoughts,
Tho' ſhe has broke her ſaith to me, to you
Againſt her Reputation, ſhe'l be true;
Farewell my firſt Love Loſt, I'le chooſe to have
No Wi • e till death ſhall wed me to my Grave,
Come Streph • n, come, and teach me how to dye,
That gav'ſt me Li • e ſo unadviſedly.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: 'T was mine I ſent it to Aphelia;
sp.stage: the King here beholds in Landreys Hat the J • wel he ſent by his Mother to Aphelia.
sp.l: Mother I've found your • inion; but no more,
The time's not ripe: ſomething I muſt do—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Call back the Monſieur, let him not
Depart ſo full of grief.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Mother content your ſelf;
Let Clovis that way go, this way will we,
He's great with grief, we with felicity.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Miſchief grows lean Caſtrato, all our Plots
Turn head upon themſelves; my brain's grown weak
And in this Globe the Policy's not leſt
To kill a Worm unſeen; I am undone
And all my Plots diſcover'd:

sp.speaker: Eunuch.
sp.l: This is Strange.
Some commick devil croſſeth our deſigns,
How elſe ſhould he revive? or you, prepar'd,
Nay, in the arms of Landrey, when deſire
Had made you all a Venus, meet events
So barren in their expectations?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: There lies the grief Caſtrato; had the Court
(So I had quencht theſe burning flames)
Been buried in her cinders I had not car • d.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: But yet Landreys eſcape does qualify
The non-performance.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: That ſits ſmiling here:
It ſet my brains upon the ten • ors, Eunuch,
Was't not a rare device?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: And was not I
As fortunate to leave that Armour there?
But now what's to be done?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: My dull Aetiope
I will inſtruct thy blackneſs, learn to know
My reputation's ſickned, and my fame
Is look'd into with narrow eyes at Court,
Therefore it's thus decreed: I will remove
And ſequeſter my ſelf from Company.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou know'ſt where Childrick kept his Concubine
To none diſcover'd but thy ſelf and me,
For which they are no more.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: There will I
And my Landrey ſecurely ſpend our time;
Revell, embrace, and what not my Eunuch?
The Cave that leads unto the Poſtern-Gate
Which Childrick made will give him entrance
No eye acquainted; being thus retired
What Luſt inſlam'd muſt be by Luſt un-ſired.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Excellent Miſtreſs I applaud your brain.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I will away to night, I cannot brook
Theſe loathed Nuptials, they have undone
My hopes on earth for ever; therefore away,
Acquaint Landrey with theſe deſigns.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: If by the engino of thy ſtronger brain
Thou could'ſt remove—

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Aphelia, or the King,
Monſieur or all, is it not ſo my Queen?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Thou haſt a brain which doth ingender thoughts
As regal as our own; which does beget
A race of rare events; what pity 'tis
Thy body ſhould be ſterril, ſith thy mind
Is of ſo pregnant and a fruitfull kind:
Farewell remember me.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Remember you, you ſhall be thought on, ſear it not.
And now bethink thee Eunuch, all thy Flots
Find fruit leſs goodneſs, only in the King:
His Worſhip walk'd into the other World
Like a tame Sucking-Child that dy'd of the Pip.
The trouble is behind, my hare extends
To the whole Family, I muſt root them up;
And Beldam firſt with you: But how? but how?
It in her proud deſires, I prevent
Her Luſt this Second time, before the Third
She may repent and ſave her loathed Soul,
Which my Revenge would Damn; yet were ſhe croſt
Her Luſt, being now at full flood within her,
And no way left to quench her burning flames,
Her dryer Bones would make a Bonefire
Fit for the Devil to warm his hands by.
Ha! Shall it be thus? No it muſt not be;
Nor muſt the high and mighty Queen Aphelia
This Night Enjoy her Bridegroom, I muſt ſet
Some Miſchief inſtantly on foot to croſs it,
If I miſcarry in't, Story ſhall tell
I did attempt it bravely tho' I fell.

div.stage: Offers to go off, & met with the M. & La.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Diſwade me not Caſtrato! I have ſought thee
Through every angle of this ſpatious Court,
I've bus'neſs to impart.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Mine are of Honourable conſequence
And do require thine aid.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Your Brother's Wife, and you
Would fain injoy her too? Why ſir you may,
But time muſt work her.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Eunuch thou art wide,
Thoſe vanities of Love are quite Extinct,
Revenge does ſwell the Monſieur, and his thoughts
Which burns within him muſt be quencht with blood,
Seeſt thou this Letter, 'tis a ſcript I ſeign'd,
For I can Counterſeit Aphelia's hand,
The King has baniſht Landrey from the Court
Becauſe he wore the Jewel which he ſent
To his Aphelia, light ſuſpicious
But this ſhall aggrevate: find thou the King,
Shew him this note, it doth expreſs great Love
To Landrey from Aphelia and withall
It mentioneth the Jewel as a gift
To gratify her ſervant, this to the reſt
Of poyſon he has ſuckt already in
Shall ſo inflame him, that the Court ſhall burn
Too Hot for his Aphelia

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Think it done:
But now your aid, ſince that your mind is bent
On Honourable deeds, here's one will try you.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: What is it Eunuch?
If that is bare an honourable Name;
Tho' death ſtood gaping wide to ſwallow me
I will not ſhrink nor fear.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Noble: Hear't then.
Your mother's looſe, and this night renders up
Her body unto luſt if not prevented,
I can direct you how, and where, with whom,
If you'l be tame, be tame, diſhonou • blots
Your Princely Parentage.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: My ſoul finds the Man
Is't not Landrey?

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: I'le tear him all to pieces,
Whore my mother? Eunuch lead the way,
In what thou ſhalt preſcribe, we will obey.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: WHat vulture gripes me here: ha, what art thou?
If thou be'ſt jelouſy, mount and be gone;
Fly to the vulgar boſome, whoſe cheap thoughts,
Deſpair their own performance; in a King
Thou ſhew'ſt a Nature retrograde to Honour.
Suppoſe ſhe gave the jewel, muſt in follow
She therefore is diſloyal, poor conſequence
A bubble for a boy to play withal.
I am reſolv'd; Heark I hear her coming:
O Juno what a gate and look is there?

div.stage: Soft Muſick. Enter Aphelia, Iſabel, Julia, with Tapers as having Aphelia to Bed.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: Mock me not Ladies with this Ceremony,
For I am ſitter to attend on you,
I am become a Servant and a Slave
To every moody Paſſion of my Lord:
Pray leave me, all that's behind
I can perform my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: That name of Queen ſounds ſtrangely in mine ears,
It's like a Language that I once could ſpeak,
But now have quite forgot, call not me Queen;
All Gilded Royalties I'le quite renounce,
And all my ſtudy ſhall be how to dye:
Empreſs of woe, and Queen fo Miſery.

sp.speaker: Jul.
sp.l: You muſt not weigh theſe things ſo deep,
Your Lord is of an honourable ſpirit,
And you will ſee how calm he will return,
Bleſſing your bridal b • d with fruitfull Iſſue.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: No, No.
The Saffron-colour'd Hymen frowns upon me:
Theſe Tapers too were lighted at a Pike,
As • it attendants on the Grave, not Bed.
Juno denye; her preſence at this match
And all the ill preſ • gi • g Birds of Night
Sing ſatal Req • iems for a bridal ſong
Oh Ladies, is not this ominous?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Yes my Aphelia if that rugged fate
Lye in a kiſs then it is ominous,
Her kiſſes melt upon my lip: if ſin
Have ſo much heaven in it, I'le be a ſinner.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: I hope your ſears are ſatisfy'd now,
You bare a brow ſo pleaſant.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: What pritty foolery is this Aphelia?
I am not jelous, for by all that's good,
I cannot think thee evil; go be gone
Unharneſs your Lady for theſe warrs,
We're of the Camills and ſight naked.
Ye powers that favour lovers, infuſe apt Strength,
Though every Nerve and Sinew of this frame
Make me all pleaſure; and unto the Bride,
Add every vein a Venus; guide me light,
Where in one Bed lyes all the Worlds delight.
What knockings this? Caſtrato, what's the news?
Deliver Briefly, for I am in haſt.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Not yet in Bed? oh happy, happy minute:
Untill this hour I ne're was fortunate,
I have preſerved my King, my Prince, my Patron,
From the looſe ardor of a Strumpets Bed.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I deal not now on doubts; your wiſe is looſe
Diſhoneſt as the Suburbs, I am loth
To nominate her Whore tho' it be true.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Leave this lethargiz'd paſſion, which benumbs
Your nobler nature; turn your eyes on theſe;
Whoſe Character is this?

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Ha! let me ſee:
This is Aphelia's hand, the very ſame
Which I have often ſeen Clovis peruſe
In his Loves amorous purſuit.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: A Letter that ſhe loves Landrey, with thanks
For his ſo often viſits; which ſhe repays
With the rich Jewel ſent her by the King,
Wiſhing a perpetuity of embracements;
Ten thouſand Ravens croak in this black paper,
How came you by it?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: I ſaw it drop from Landrey, but ne're thought
'Fore I perus'd it, what it did contain;
Which finding, in my duty I was bound
To ſave my Prince from ruine.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Follow me
Black vengeance ſteel my heart with cruelty.
I'le take her ſleeping thus; it cannot be,
sp.stage: a Bed thruſt forth with Aphelia in it, Enter Clot. again and the Eunuch.
sp.l: Do but behold her face, and thou ſhalt read
What we call virtue there and modeſty;
Here is a look would perſuade cruelty
To ſigh and ſhed a tear, bribe Nemeſis
To knot her Steely Scourge with plumie down,
And Jove himſelf to call her vice a virtue.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: A book of Devils may have the cover gilt,
Treaſon lies cabben'd in the ſmootheſt brow,
The Devil can aſſume an Angels form,
Your Wife is fair, but fair to do you harm.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Peace Villain, thou that infects all peace.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Why are you thus diſtemper'd? let not truth
Make you ſo wild a Tempeſt; were it falſe,
Or that I ſhought the ruine of your houſe
Your youth and honour, then it were a time
To ſwell beyond all charming down:
But being truth!

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Hence dog, avoid my ſight,
Fly where the under-world, ill vers'd in kindred,
Promiſcuouſly combine without diſtinction,
Where every man is every womans husband,
Or where it's thought a curteſy to have,
A fellow-ſharer in the marriage-bed:
Theſe were a People that might bare with thee
And ſit for thee to dwell with; hence, away,
And if thou lov'ſt thy life acquaint thy feet
With ſuch by paths that we may never meet.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: This Prince is of a nature milde and gentle,
His mother's milk's too fluent in his eyes,
And much I fear his reſolution;
Yet I will work him forward; ſhe awakes;
I'le after him and bring him back, if then
She ſcape his rage, Hell has no power with men.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: Oh, oh, oh, help, help, my Lord, my Lord, my Father,
Oh my Lord.
Bleſs me Divinity, 'twas but a Dream;
Ha! the light gone, who waits there, Iſabel, Julia, Iſabel.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: That was my Ladies voice; calls ſhe for help?
I cannot blame her, were I in her place
I ſhould do ſo my ſelf; the Prince looks like a bungler.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.p: Saw'ſt thou nothing Iſabel? where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: Is he abſent? I cannot blame her then to call for help;
I ſhould do't my ſelf; ſo near a good turn, and delay'd,
O it would mad me; a Prince, a Puppet would have
Been more manly; How do you Madam?

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: O Girl, I've paſt the diſmal'ſt part of night
That ever made ſoft fancy fo • l.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.p: If all Brides ſhould be ſo ſool'd, I'de forſwear Marriage.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: Methought I ſaw my Father in a Vault,
His ſilver hair made crimſon by his bloud,
My Brother at his Herſe upon his knees
Taking a ſolemn Oath for his revenge,
Yet all this while ſo fancy fool'd my ſenſe
Methought that I was here, when on the inſtant
My Lord in preparation for my bed,
Was by an ugly Fiend raviſht from hence
And hurried to deſtruction, here I waked,
And truſt me Iſabel, I ſcarce believe
But what I ſaw was real. Heard'ſt thou nothing?

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: I heard diſcourſe of People in your chamber
Not half an hour ſince: but they went forth
And to my ſeeming full of diſcontent,
But know not who they were.

sp.speaker: Aph.
sp.l: Oh it is true, help me Iſabel,
I'le to my Fathers, my Prophetique ſoul
Sits like a Mine of Lead within me,
Come Girl.

sp.speaker: Iſab.
sp.l: This ſad fight
Beſits a funeral, not a bridal night.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Eunuch I'me reſolved, I will be cruel
Since ſhe's deſil'd, and like a Chryſtal Well
That has her ſpring poyſoned by the enemy,
Of which it's death for the beſieg'd to taſte,
Such are adulterate waters. Caſtrato
What read'ſt thou in our brow?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: A fooliſh grudging of the mother ſtill.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: A ſettled reſolution my black Saint
Not to be alter'd by the brackiſh tears
Which flow in pregnant eyes of eaſy woman,
My honour calls for vengeance, and I'le do;
Ha, how! ſhe's gone, and I have loſt mine anger too.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: But whither is ſhe gone, to ſome new Groom,
Who being fool'd in expectation
Will make thee Cuckold on thy wedding night.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Thou haſt awaked me, I'le know where ſhe is;
Hell nor her darker deeds ſhall hide her from me:
Who waites? La-key.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.p: Where is thy Lady? where is Aphelia?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.l: There was one with her, but whether man or woman
I am uncertain; but ſure it was a man,
ſhe would not dare to venture out ſo late elſe.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Get to thy reſt
I'le take thy word Eunuch for the Kingdoms wealth.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Oh d'ye begin to credit now,
Now when perhaps it is too late.
This comes of patience.

sp.speaker: Clot.
sp.l: Turn patience into fury, love to hate;
My ſofter temper to a heart of Steel;
Reſpect to Wedlock and the Sacred Vow
Made 'fore the Holy Alter to the Prieſt,
Thus I do fling ye off; Revenge ſhall move
About our Bridal-bed inſtead of Love.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Clovis, Strephon, and the Watch.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.p: Upon your lives let no man paſs that way.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: If he reſiſt or offer violence
In his eſcape, knock out his brains.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.p: We'le do our beſt my Lord.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: There's your reward, be carefull and be gone.
You ſhall poſſeſs the Cave: my ſelf will in
And viſit theſe night-revellers, ſuch ſport
I will adminiſter, ſhall make them dance
Lauolto's in the air; this ſhall Fiddle to them:
Have you the Habit Strephon?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: With theſe hands I did diſ • robe the Statue of your Father.
And they are ready.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Landrey, bloud does ſwell
The Monſieur's thoughts, to ſend thy ſoul to Hell.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Landrey ſolus. Muſique above plays.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: The air's perfum'd, each room thro' which I walk

Baqu •• s the 〈◊〉
• ſ • s, courts the appetite
O • every la •• l • y • hat makes up man
To complement 〈◊〉 into Paradiſe:
If then Elyſiun • 's h •• e, where are thoſe ſhades,
Thoſe bleſſed apparitions Poets feign?
Appear my goddeſs and out-ſing the Poets.
Reality of fancy, that exelleſt
The faint expreſſion of a lazy tongue
Whoſe roof is hous'd with fleſh, to tell thy worth,
Tongues tipt with Immortality would faint in't.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Excellent ſervant, what Houſe do you write to?
Poet and Actor both! why this ſudden gaze?
Your caſes are too narrow for your eyes,
Pray keep your optiques Sir, for Venus ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: No,
I'le play the Prodigal with my precious ſight,
And ſpend all on you; to view your ſecond
Were ſuch a happineſs, after tho which,
It were a ſin to ſee more.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Bleſs me Rablais!
And all ye foſter fancies of the French,
What ails the man! my Landrey-Laureat?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: It is my Queen that's Laureat, whoſe bleſt ſight
Creates a Poet; this divine feature
Heaven only fram'd to make men ingenuous.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Is this Extempore? or have you hired
Some Hackney-Muſe acquainted with the road
Of vulgar exorciſms, to charm ſweet Beauties?
Take up at this ſpeed, elſe your Muſe will founder.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Founder and have her foundreſs by! with patience
Hear but theſe poor expreſſion of your worth,
Which faintly Paint forth your perfections,
And you ſhall bleſs my Muſe.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: We'le hear your Jigg,
How is your Ballad Titled? come pronounce.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: From head to foot my Miſtreſs been
Far excelling beauties Queen.
Had Jaſon but beheld her hair,
The Golden-Fleece had ne're ſeem'd fair.
Thoſe Stars (which Mortals ſuppoſe eyes),
Were aſcendant in the Skies:
When it fell to Venus lot
That little Cupid was begot.
Her tongue, (in which the Spheres do move
Organ of divineſt Love)
Was by Apollo fram'd, that he
From: hence might learn more harmony.
Who notes her teeth, and lips, diſcoloſes
Walls of Pearl, and Gates of Roſes,
Two-leaved-doors that lead the way
Through her breath t'Arabia;
To which would Cupid grant that bliſs
I'de go a Pilgrimage to kiſs
Thoſe hills of Snow which on her breaſt
Riſe ſwelling with a double Creſt.
Mate Parnaſſus mountain, whence,
The Muſes ſuck their Eloquence.
Thoſe Parts which we will not diſcover,
He'l imagine that's a Lover.
Like Juno ſhe does go,
Like Pailas talk, and ſow,
Like Venus in her bliſs,
Each kiſs a Cupid is.
And her hands are as White as ſnow.
From head to foot &c.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Leave theſe aerial viands, taſt of what
Is here ſubſtantial; How like you the fruit?

sp.speaker: Land.
sp.p: Let me for ever dwell upon theſe lips;

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: You are too greedy of thoſe rarities;
And muſt be dieted, leſt ſurfeting,
Your Appetite ſhould ſicken and ſo dye.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: Dye on your Lips, oh death-bed for a Jove
Whoſe buried here his grave's immortal Love.
Here will I dwell and know not age nor ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: A Froſty Prince
Begot on January by a Dutchman,
And worthy of thoſe flames he now indures.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: What noiſe is this? guard me divinity.

div.stage: Enter Clov. from under the Stage in the old Kings habit, Land. flys off, the Qu. ſwoons: he flings • ffkis habit & holds her up.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: What has my raſhneſs done! ſhe's my mother
My conſcience tells me I was much too blame
Thus to delude her ſenſes; ſhe returns.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh Childrick I confeſs 'twas I that kil'd thee,
Theſe hands adminiſtred that fatal dram
Which ſet thy ſoud on wing.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: Oh do not ſnatch my ſoul from out the world
Till I have bath'd it in repenting tears
And made it fit for Heaven.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: She faints again.
O Welcome Strephon, lend thy gentle hand
Which Maſter's Nature, and does life reſtore;
Beyond the art of Eſculapius,
Apply thy gentleſt medicines.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Let us withdraw, my life Sir anſwer hers if ſhe miſcarry.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.p: 1. Stand cloſe, ſtand cloſe, I heard a kind of buſsling e're while.
2. Buſsling, and they come this way here's that ſhall buſsle them.
3. Peace, peace; he's drunk and will betray us all.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.l: I am betray'd, the Monſieur ſeeks my life,
All ways againſt my eſcape are ſortify'd.
Oh cruel Fortune, Bawd to time and Fate
That ſootheſt us up to make us ruinate.
Ha, what is here? great goddeſs pardon me,
sp.stage: he finds the habie and puts it on.
sp.l: I have offended 'gainſt thy deity.
This ſhall delude the Watch; thrice bleſſed hap
That thus delivereſt whom they would intrap.
I will no ſtand, or I cannot ſtand, I ſay
sp.stage: they pull the drunken Watchman to be quiet.
sp.l: I ſee a voice, d' • e think I'me drunk, what's
That horrid ſmell, what's that?

sp.p: Bleſs us oh bleſs; diabolo, diabolo, diabolo.

sp.l: The devil, what devil care I; keep off devil,
I ſay keep off; I do not fear thee: are you ſneaking
Back, you cowardly rogue d'ye budge; I hate a cowardly
Devil as I hate a drunkard, take you that.
Oh, oh; I'le warrant you I'le make you cry oh: what a devil
Made you in my way: I will now ſee what money you carry
About you: men ſay the Prince of darkneſs is a Gentleman;
By'r Lady he ha good cloaths on, but yet for all that
He may have no money.

div.stage: Enter Clovis, Strephon, and the Queen. Strephon with his falſe Beard off.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: I know not where he is, or if I did,
Before I'de yield him up to thy revenge
I'de dye ten thouſand deaths.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: For ſo I ſtill muſt call thee, thou haſt ſeen,
And heard thoſe things delivered, that do ſplie
My heart in ſunder, yet amongſt theſe griefs
Which ſit like Mines of Lead upon my ſoul
There is one corner of my heart that joys
Thy innocent bloud has ſcaped butchery.
Thou glorious light that in thine natural orb
Did'ſt comfortably ſhine upon this Kingdom,
How is thy worth eclypſed? what a dull darkneſs
Hangs about thy ſame? in all this piece
To every limb whereof I once paid duty,
I know not where to find my Mother.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: The devil and diſobedience blinds your eyes.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Oh that I had no eyes, ſo you no ſhame:
Murther your Husband to arrive at Luſt,
And then to lay the guilt on innocents:
Bluſh, bluſh thou worſe then Woman.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Hold my heart,
You're impudent in ſin, has your proud Page
Made you thus valiant? tell me where he is,
For if you dally with me, know this hand
Shall pull him from thy heart tho' cabbin'd there.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: How dar'ſt thou cloath thy ſpeech in ſuch a phraſe
To me thy natural Mother?

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: My Mother!
Adulterate woman, ſhame of Royalty
I bluſh to call thee Mother: thy foul Luſts
Have taught me words of that harſh conſequence
That ſtigmatize obedience, and do brand
With miſ becoming accents filial duty.
Deliver quickly where this Leacher is,
Here hous'd he muſt be, for he cannot 'ſcape,
Leſt wildneſs conquering my ſafer ſenſe
Thruſt forth my hand into and act of horror,
And leave you breathleſs here. Will you diſcloſe?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: What French Neronian Spirit have we here?
Inſolent boy wilt thou turn Parracide?

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: The Juſtice of my cauſe would well excuſe me,
Iſ I ſhould execute: ſpeak Murthereſs,
Where have you mew'd your Monſter?
Here lies the Monſter; O rare Monſter; two beards, I'le pul
On this too that's certain, two heads O delicate dainty Monſter.
What a brave Monſter ſhall I be, the Conſtable himſelf.
sp.stage: he in the Habit of Child. offers to ſteal by.
sp.l: Cannot make a better Monſter, I will ſteal by theſe, get
Me home, ſell theſe gay cloaths, buy half a dram of Juſtice
And be a Monſter of the Peace immediately.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Will you confeſs, or—drop oh mine eye-balls out
And thou my ſollid fleſh diſſolve to earth.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: How fares it with your Grace? Great Monſieur ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Look there Lamot ſeeſt thou that horrid ſhape,
Which I unjuſtly did but now uſurp;
Looks it not like the King, Lamot what ſay'ſt thou?
Shall I go kneel to't, call it honour'd Father,
And beg a pardon for my treſpaſs done?
It would depart, but I will call it back:
Stay thou bleſt ſpirit, Royal father, thru,
Behold thy ſon, thy Clovis on his knees,
O pardon gentle ſpirit pardon me.
That's my good Boy, riſe, but d'ye hear ſirrah,
Put no more tricks nor gulls upon me; my ſon,
I have but one and he's three quarters rogue by this time;
He's e'n as like thee as over he can peep,
Bleſs my Boy, I like him n're the better for't

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: What ſtrange illuſion's this? what art thou, ſpeak,
Or I will nail thee dead againſt the wall.
Juſt ſuch another Rogue have I to my ſon as this;
He has his very words too, thou art mine own,
I wonder where I got thee, canſt not thou remember?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Villain?
How cam'ſt thou by that babit? who ar't, ſpeak?
Is it the Monſieur? I have made a brave hand on't then;
Lord, Lord, ſee how good cloaths makes us forget our ſelves:
My name is Potſhot, my trade a Cobler,
One of the Conſtables Watch in extraordinary;
And if you will believe me Mr. Monſieur,
It went againſt my ſtomach very much,
That you ſhould daro preſume to call me father,
Oh, oh, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Colv.
sp.p: Tell me how thou cam'ſt by thoſe cloaths? I'le pardon thee.

sp.l: Truly I came lawfully by them, for I ſtole them,
The devil and I fought 15 hours for them,
He broke my head a dozen times at leaſt;
At l • ſt I maul'd the raſcal, and he lies there.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.l: Behold my Lord, the Woodcock's in the gin,
Here lies the great Landrey.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: This habit might have ruin'd all, Lamot,
But Goblin now you're caught; what is he dead?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Scarce hurt my Lord; how is it Sir, look up?

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.p: Hold hold, you have done well.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Here Eunuch as thou ſeeſt in miſery.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: On my heart, how came they hither? Lamot too?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: All that I know is that we are betray'd.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: I'le ſet them packing fear't nor; My good Lord

sp.l: D'ye hear friend Lucifer, what Cat's your father?
How many lives have you got, ha diabolo?

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Give them a nobler title, by my life
I do applaud their courage, come they on?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Yes, and Br • ſſac is made their General.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: A hopefull Youth fraught with nobility,
And all the gracefull qualities that write.
Man truly honourable, mine injuries.
Have ſtirr'd him up to this.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Truſt me I'me ſorry for't, grief has broke his heart.
And mine Caſtrato, too: can'ſt thou imagine
Who was the authors of our father's death?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: Am I betray'd, then, lend mo confidence,
I'me ſure I cannot bluſh; Royal Sir, whom?

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Our Mother and Landrey, and this Lamot.
They meant ſhould bear the blame: this was Strephon.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: It's wondrous ſtrange, Would I were fairly off.

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.p: But what news with Aphelia, and her Bridegroom?

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.l: As you could wiſh, he's full of ielouſy,
No Frenchman e're was more Italian,
I've wrought him bravely on, your Phyſick works;
Hither I've brought Aphelia too: tomorrow
You ſhall hear further; ſport I'le warrant you.
What will you do with theſe?

sp.speaker: Clov.
sp.l: Caſtrato, thus:
Nature forbids me ſpill my Mothers bloud,
For I muſt ſtudy torments for the ſlave,
Therefore I give them upto your tuition
Untill we ſhall return victorious.

sp.speaker: Qu.
